The **Church of England** (**C of E**) is the [Established
Church](/wiki/State_religion#Protestantism "State religion") of
[England](/wiki/England "England").[3][4][5] The [Archbishop of
Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury") is the
most senior cleric, although the
[monarch](/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom "Monarchy of the United
Kingdom") is the [supreme
governor](/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England "Supreme Governor of
the Church of England"). The Church of England is also the [mother
church](/wiki/Mother_church "Mother church") of the international [Anglican
Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican Communion"). It traces its
history to the Christian church recorded as existing in the Roman province of
Britain by the third century, and to the 6th-century [Gregorian
mission](/wiki/Gregorian_mission "Gregorian mission") to
[Kent](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kent "Kingdom of Kent") led by [Augustine of
Canterbury](/wiki/Augustine_of_Canterbury "Augustine of Canterbury").[6][7][8]

The English church renounced [papal](/wiki/Papal "Papal") authority when
[Henry VIII](/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England "Henry VIII of England") failed to
secure an [annulment](/wiki/Annulment "Annulment") of his marriage to
[Catherine of Aragon](/wiki/Catherine_of_Aragon "Catherine of Aragon") in
1534.[9] The [English Reformation](/wiki/English_Reformation "English
Reformation") accelerated under [Edward VI](/wiki/Edward_VI_of_England "Edward
VI of England")'s regents, before a brief [restoration of papal
authority](/wiki/Second_Statute_of_Repeal "Second Statute of Repeal") under
[Queen Mary I](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I of England") and [King
Philip](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain"). The [Act of Supremacy
1558](/wiki/Act_of_Supremacy_1558 "Act of Supremacy 1558") renewed the breach
and the [Elizabethan Settlement](/wiki/Elizabethan_Settlement "Elizabethan
Settlement") charted a course enabling the English church to describe itself
as both catholic and reformed:

  * _catholic_ in that it views itself as a part of the universal church of [Jesus Christ](/wiki/Jesus_Christ "Jesus Christ") in unbroken continuity with the early [apostolic](/wiki/Apostolic_Age "Apostolic Age") church. This is expressed in its emphasis on the teachings of the early [Church Fathers](/wiki/Church_Fathers "Church Fathers"), as formalised in the [Apostles'](/wiki/Apostles%27_Creed "Apostles' Creed"), [Nicene](/wiki/Nicene_Creed "Nicene Creed"), and [Athanasian](/wiki/Athanasian_Creed "Athanasian Creed") creeds.[10]
  * _reformed_ in that it has been shaped by some of the doctrinal principles of the 16th-century [Protestant Reformation](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation "Protestant Reformation"), in particular in the [Thirty-Nine Articles of Religion](/wiki/Thirty-Nine_Articles_of_Religion "Thirty-Nine Articles of Religion") and the [Book of Common Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer "Book of Common Prayer").[10]

In the earlier phase of the [English Reformation](/wiki/English_Reformation
"English Reformation") there were both [Catholic
martyrs](/wiki/List_of_Catholic_martyrs_of_the_English_Reformation "List of
Catholic martyrs of the English Reformation") and [radical
Protestant](/wiki/List_of_Protestant_martyrs_of_the_English_Reformation "List
of Protestant martyrs of the English Reformation") martyrs. The later phases
saw the [Penal Laws](/wiki/English_Penal_Laws "English Penal Laws") punish
Roman Catholic and [nonconforming Protestants](/wiki/Nonconformist
"Nonconformist"). In the 17th century, the [Puritan](/wiki/Puritan "Puritan")
and [Presbyterian](/wiki/Presbyterian "Presbyterian") factions continued to
challenge the leadership of the Church which under the Stuarts veered towards
a more catholic interpretation of the Elizabethan Settlement especially under
Archbishop Laud and the rise of the concept of Anglicanism as the Via Media.
After the victory of the Parliamentarians the Prayer Book was abolished and
the Presbyterian and Independent factions dominated. The Episcopacy was
abolished. The [Restoration](/wiki/Restoration_\(1660\) "Restoration
\(1660\)") restored the Church of England, episcopacy and the Prayer Book.
Papal recognition of [George III](/wiki/George_III_of_England "George III of
England") in 1766 led to greater religious tolerance.

Since the English Reformation, the Church of England has used a
[liturgy](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy") in English. The church contains several
doctrinal strands, the main three known as [Anglo-Catholic](/wiki/Anglo-
Catholic "Anglo-Catholic"), [Evangelical](/wiki/Evangelical_Anglicanism
"Evangelical Anglicanism") and [Broad Church](/wiki/Broad_Church "Broad
Church"). Tensions between theological conservatives and progressives find
expression in debates over the [ordination of
women](/wiki/Ordination_of_women_in_the_Anglican_Communion "Ordination of
women in the Anglican Communion") and
[homosexuality](/wiki/Homosexuality_and_Anglicanism "Homosexuality and
Anglicanism"). The church includes both [liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Christianity
"Liberal Christianity") and
[conservative](/wiki/British_Conservative_Evangelicalism "British Conservative
Evangelicalism") clergy and members.[11]

The governing structure of the church is based on [dioceses](/wiki/Diocese
"Diocese"), each presided over by a bishop. Within each diocese are local
parishes. The [General Synod of the Church of
England](/wiki/General_Synod_of_the_Church_of_England "General Synod of the
Church of England") is the legislative body for the church and comprises
bishops, other clergy and [laity](/wiki/Laity "Laity"). Its measures must be
approved by both [Houses of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom
"Parliament of the United Kingdom").
