## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Main article: [History of the Church of
England](/wiki/History_of_the_Church_of_England "History of the Church of
England")

### Early Christianity in
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early Christianity in England")]

Main articles: [History of Christianity in
England](/wiki/History_of_Christianity_in_England "History of Christianity in
England") and [Anglo-Saxon Christianity](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Christianity
"Anglo-Saxon Christianity")

According to tradition, Christianity arrived in Britain in the
[1st](/wiki/Christianity_in_the_1st_century "Christianity in the 1st century")
or [2nd century](/wiki/Christianity_in_the_2nd_century "Christianity in the
2nd century"), during which time southern Britain became part of the [Roman
Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"). The earliest historical evidence
of Christianity among the native [Britons](/wiki/Britons_\(historical\)
"Britons \(historical\)") is found in the writings of such early Christian
Fathers as [Tertullian](/wiki/Tertullian "Tertullian") and
[Origen](/wiki/Origen "Origen") in the first years of the [3rd
century](/wiki/Christianity_in_the_3rd_century "Christianity in the 3rd
century"). Three [Romano-British](/wiki/Romano-British "Romano-British")
bishops, including [Restitutus](/wiki/Restitutus "Restitutus"), are known to
have been present at the [Council of Arles in
314](/wiki/Council_of_Arles_\(314\) "Council of Arles \(314\)").[12] Others
attended the [Council of Serdica](/wiki/Council_of_Serdica "Council of
Serdica") in 347 and that of [Ariminum](/wiki/Council_of_Ariminum "Council of
Ariminum") in 360, and a number of references to the church in [Roman
Britain](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain") are found in the writings of
[4th century](/wiki/Christianity_in_the_4th_century "Christianity in the 4th
century") Christian fathers. Britain was the home of [Pelagius](/wiki/Pelagius
"Pelagius"), who opposed [Augustine of Hippo](/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo
"Augustine of Hippo")'s doctrine of [original sin](/wiki/Original_sin
"Original sin").[13]

While Christianity was long established as the religion of the Britons at the
time of the [Anglo-Saxon invasion](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_invasion_of_Britain
"Anglo-Saxon invasion of Britain"), Christian Britons made little progress in
converting the newcomers from their [native paganism](/wiki/Anglo-
Saxon_paganism "Anglo-Saxon paganism"). Consequently, in 597, [Pope Gregory
I](/wiki/Pope_Gregory_I "Pope Gregory I") sent the [prior](/wiki/Prior
"Prior") of the [Abbey of St Andrew's](/wiki/San_Gregorio_Magno_al_Celio "San
Gregorio Magno al Celio") (later canonised as [Augustine of
Canterbury](/wiki/Augustine_of_Canterbury "Augustine of Canterbury")) from
Rome to evangelise the [Angles](/wiki/Angles "Angles"). This event is known as
the [Gregorian mission](/wiki/Gregorian_mission "Gregorian mission") and is
the date the Church of England generally marks as the beginning of its formal
history. With the help of Christians already residing in
[Kent](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kent "Kingdom of Kent"), Augustine established his
church at [Canterbury](/wiki/Canterbury "Canterbury"), the capital of the
[Kingdom of Kent](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kent "Kingdom of Kent"), and became the
first in the series of [Archbishops of
Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishops_of_Canterbury "Archbishops of Canterbury") in
598. A later archbishop, the Greek [Theodore of
Tarsus](/wiki/Theodore_of_Tarsus "Theodore of Tarsus"), also contributed to
the organisation of Christianity in England. The Church of England has been in
continuous existence since the days of St Augustine, with the Archbishop of
Canterbury as its episcopal head. Despite the various disruptions of the
Reformation and the [English Civil War](/wiki/English_Civil_War "English Civil
War"), the Church of England considers itself to be the same church which was
more formally organised by Augustine.[6]

While some Celtic Christian practices were changed at the [Synod of
Whitby](/wiki/Synod_of_Whitby "Synod of Whitby"), the Christian in the British
Isles was under papal authority from earliest times.[14] Queen [Bertha of
Kent](/wiki/Bertha_of_Kent "Bertha of Kent") was among the Christians in
England who recognised papal authority before Augustine arrived,[15] and
Celtic Christians were carrying out missionary work with papal approval long
before the Synod of Whitby.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Hereford_Cathedral_Interior_May_2004.jpg/220px-
Hereford_Cathedral_Interior_May_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hereford_Cathedral_Interior_May_2004.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hereford_Cathedral_Interior_May_2004.jpg "Enlarge")

[Hereford](/wiki/Hereford_Cathedral "Hereford Cathedral") is one of the
church's 43 cathedrals; many have histories stretching back centuries

The Synod of Whitby established the Roman date for Easter and the Roman style
of monastic tonsure in England. This meeting of the ecclesiastics with Roman
customs with local bishops was summoned in 664 at Saint Hilda's double
monastery of Streonshalh (Streanæshalch), later called [Whitby
Abbey](/wiki/Whitby_Abbey "Whitby Abbey"). It was presided over by [King
Oswiu](/wiki/Oswiu "Oswiu"), who did not engage in the debate but made the
final ruling.

### Separation from
Rome[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Separation from Rome")]

In 1534, [King Henry VIII](/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England "Henry VIII of
England") separated the English Church from Rome.[9] A theological separation
had been foreshadowed by various movements within the English Church, such as
[Lollardy](/wiki/Lollardy "Lollardy"), but the English Reformation gained
political support when Henry VIII wanted an [annulment](/wiki/Annulment
"Annulment") of his marriage to [Catherine of
Aragon](/wiki/Catherine_of_Aragon "Catherine of Aragon") so he could marry
[Anne Boleyn](/wiki/Anne_Boleyn "Anne Boleyn"). [Pope Clement
VII](/wiki/Pope_Clement_VII "Pope Clement VII"), considering that the earlier
marriage had been entered under a [papal
dispensation](/wiki/Dispensation_\(canon_law\) "Dispensation \(canon law\)")
and how Catherine's nephew, [Emperor Charles
V](/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor"), might
react to such a move, refused the annulment. Eventually, Henry, although
theologically opposed to Protestantism, took the position of [Supreme Head of
the Church of England](/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England
"Supreme Governor of the Church of England") to ensure the annulment of his
marriage. He was [excommunicated](/wiki/Excommunicated "Excommunicated") by
[Pope Paul III](/wiki/Pope_Paul_III "Pope Paul III").[16]

In 1536–40 Henry VIII engaged in the [Dissolution of the
Monasteries](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Monasteries "Dissolution of the
Monasteries"), which controlled much of the richest land. He disbanded
[monasteries](/wiki/Monastery "Monastery"), [priories](/wiki/Priory "Priory"),
[convents](/wiki/Convent "Convent") and [friaries](/wiki/Friary "Friary") in
England, Wales and Ireland, appropriated their income, disposed of their
assets, and provided pensions for the former residents. The properties were
sold to pay for the wars. Bernard argues:

    The dissolution of the monasteries in the late 1530s was one of the most revolutionary events in English history. There were nearly 900 religious houses in England, around 260 for monks, 300 for regular canons, 142 nunneries and 183 friaries; some 12,000 people in total, 4,000 monks, 3,000 canons, 3,000 friars and 2,000 nuns....one adult man in fifty was in religious orders.[17]

The population of England at the time is estimated to have been only 2.5
million: half male of whom 750,000 adult. This is one in 75, not 1 in 50.
However the latter figure is creditable if secular clergy are included.

Henry maintained a strong preference for traditional Catholic practices and,
during his reign, Protestant reformers were unable to make many changes to the
practices of the Church of England. Indeed, this part of Henry's reign saw
trials for heresy of Protestants as well as Roman Catholics.

Under his son, [King Edward VI](/wiki/Edward_VI_of_England "Edward VI of
England"), more Protestant-influenced forms of worship were adopted. Under the
leadership of the Archbishop of Canterbury, [Thomas
Cranmer](/wiki/Thomas_Cranmer "Thomas Cranmer"), a more radical reformation
proceeded. A new pattern of worship was set out in the [Book of Common
Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer "Book of Common Prayer") (1549 and 1552).
These were based on the older liturgy in particular the Prayer Book of 1549,
but both influenced by Protestant doctrines such as justification by faith
alone, the rejection of the sacrifice of the Mass, and the Real Presence
understood as physical presence (Cranmer was Calvinist in that he believed
Christ was truly and really present in the Eucharist but after a spiritual
manner as in a sacrament). The confession of the reformed Church of England
was set out in the [Forty-two Articles](/wiki/Forty-two_Articles "Forty-two
Articles") (later revised to thirty-nine). The reformation however was cut
short by the death of the king. [Queen Mary I](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I
of England"), who succeeded him, returned England again to the authority of
the papacy, thereby ending the first attempt at an independent Church of
England. During her co-reign with her husband, [King
Philip](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain"), many leaders and
common people were burnt for their refusal to recant of their reformed faith.
These are known as the [Marian martyrs](/wiki/Marian_martyrs "Marian martyrs")
and the persecution led to her nickname of "Bloody Mary".

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Rochester_cathedral_stained_glass_2.jpg/220px-
Rochester_cathedral_stained_glass_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rochester_cathedral_stained_glass_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rochester_cathedral_stained_glass_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Stained glass window in [Rochester Cathedral](/wiki/Rochester_Cathedral
"Rochester Cathedral"), Kent

Mary also died childless and so it was left to the new regime of her half-
sister Elizabeth to resolve the direction of the church. The settlement under
[Queen Elizabeth I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of England")
(from 1558), known as the [Elizabethan
Settlement](/wiki/Elizabethan_Settlement "Elizabethan Settlement"), tried to
stir a middle way between radical Protestantism and Roman Catholicism, the
_via media,_ (a term that actually only became current in the 1620s), as the
character of the Church of England, a church moderately Reformed in doctrine,
as expressed in the [Thirty-Nine Articles](/wiki/Thirty-Nine_Articles "Thirty-
Nine Articles"), but also emphasising continuity with the Catholic and
Apostolic traditions of the [Church Fathers](/wiki/Church_Fathers "Church
Fathers"). The three-fold ministry in the Apostolic Succession was maintained;
the institutional continuity of the Church was preserved without break (at her
accession almost all clergy had been ordained in Catholic Orders using the
Roman Pontifical), although the character of the organization was changed by
the adoption of some reformed doctrines and the simplification of the outwards
forms of worship and the abandonment of traditional vestments and art work;
the retention of medieval Canon Law, a much shortened Calendar of Saints and
liturgical music. It was also an [established church](/wiki/Established_church
"Established church") (constitutionally established by the state with the Head
of State as its [supreme
governor](/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England "Supreme Governor of
the Church of England")). The exact nature of the relationship between church
and state would be a source of continued friction into the next century.

### Stuart
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Stuart period")]

Further information: [Stuart period](/wiki/Stuart_period "Stuart period")

For the next century, through the reigns of [James I](/wiki/James_VI_and_I
"James VI and I"), who ordered the translation of the Bible known as the King
James Version (Authorized to be used in parishes which does not mean it was
the official version),[18] and [Charles I](/wiki/Charles_I_of_England "Charles
I of England"), culminating in the [English Civil War](/wiki/English_Civil_War
"English Civil War") and the Protectorate of [Oliver
Cromwell](/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell "Oliver Cromwell"), there were significant
swings back and forth between two factions: the [Puritans](/wiki/Puritans
"Puritans") (and other radicals) who sought more far-reaching Protestant
reforms, and the more conservative churchmen who aimed to keep closer to
traditional beliefs and Catholic practices. The failure of political and
ecclesiastical authorities to submit to Puritan demands for more extensive
reform was one of the causes of open warfare. By Continental standards the
level of violence over religion was not high, since the Civil was mainly about
politics, but the casualties included King Charles I and the Archbishop of
Canterbury, [William Laud](/wiki/William_Laud "William Laud") and tens of
thousands of civilians who died from the unsettled conditions. Under the
Commonwealth and the Protectorate of England from 1649 to 1660, the bishops
were dethroned and former practices were outlawed, and
[Presbyterian](/wiki/Presbyterian_polity "Presbyterian polity") ecclesiology
was introduced in place of the episcopate. The 39 Articles were replaced by
the [Westminster Confession](/wiki/Westminster_Confession "Westminster
Confession"), the Book of Common Prayer by the Directory of Public Worship.
Despite this, about one quarter of English clergy refused to conform to this
form of State Presbyterianism.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/CANTEBURY_ALTAR_HORIZONTAL_7424.jpg/220px-
CANTEBURY_ALTAR_HORIZONTAL_7424.jpg)](/wiki/File:CANTEBURY_ALTAR_HORIZONTAL_7424.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CANTEBURY_ALTAR_HORIZONTAL_7424.jpg "Enlarge")

Major repairs were done to Canterbury Cathedral after the Restoration in 1660

With the Restoration of Charles II, Parliament restored the Church of England
to a form not far removed from the Elizabethan version. One difference was
that the ideal of encompassing all the people of England in one religious
organisation, taken for granted by the Tudors, had to be abandoned. The
religious landscape of England assumed its present form, with the Anglican
established church occupying the middle ground, and those Puritans and
Protestants who [dissented](/wiki/English_Dissenters "English Dissenters")
from the Anglican establishment, having to continue their existence outside
the national church rather than trying to influence or trying to gain control
of it. One result of the Restoration was the ousting of 2,000 parish ministers
who had not been ordained by bishops in the Apostolic Succession or had been
by presbyters (ministers in presbyter's orders). Continuing official suspicion
and legal restrictions continued well into the 19th century. Roman Catholics,
perhaps 5% of the English population (down from 20% in 1600) were grudgingly
tolerated, having had little or no official representation after the Pope's
excommunication of Queen Elizabeth in 1570, though the Stuarts were
sympathetic to them. In the 18th century they dwindled to 1% of the population
mostly among eccentric gentry and their tenants and extended families.

### 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 19th century")]

By the Fifth Article of the [Union with Ireland 1800](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800
"Acts of Union 1800"), the Church of England and [Church of
Ireland](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland "Church of Ireland") were united into "one
Protestant Episcopal church, to be called, the United Church of England and
Ireland".[19] Although this union was declared "an essential and fundamental
Part of the Union",[20] the [Irish Church Act
1869](/wiki/Irish_Church_Act_1869 "Irish Church Act 1869") separated the Irish
part of the church again and disestablished it, the Act coming into effect on
1 January 1871.

### Overseas
developments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Overseas developments")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/John_Smith_1624_map_of_Bermuda_with_Forts_01.jpg/200px-
John_Smith_1624_map_of_Bermuda_with_Forts_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_Smith_1624_map_of_Bermuda_with_Forts_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_Smith_1624_map_of_Bermuda_with_Forts_01.jpg "Enlarge")

Captain [John Smith's](/wiki/John_Smith_of_Jamestown "John Smith of
Jamestown") 1624 map of Bermuda, showing St Peter's at centre, left

Main article: [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican
Communion")

Further information: [Historical development of Church of England dioceses §
Colonial
dioceses](/wiki/Historical_development_of_Church_of_England_dioceses#Colonial_dioceses
"Historical development of Church of England dioceses")

As the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") expanded,
British colonists and colonial administrators took the established church
doctrines and practices together with ordained ministry and formed overseas
branches of the Church of England. As they developed or, beginning with the
United States of America, became sovereign or independent states, many of
their churches became separate organisationally but remained linked to the
Church of England through the [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion
"Anglican Communion").

In Bermuda, the oldest remaining English colony (now designated a [British
Overseas Territory](/wiki/British_Overseas_Territory "British Overseas
Territory")), the first Church of England services were performed by the
Reverend Richard Buck, one of the survivors of the 1609 wreck of the _[Sea
Venture](/wiki/Sea_Venture "Sea Venture")_ which initiated Bermuda's permanent
settlement. The nine parishes of the Church of England in
[Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda"), each with its own church and [glebe
land](/wiki/Glebe "Glebe"), rarely had more than a pair of ordained ministers
to share between them until the Nineteenth Century. From 1825 to 1839,
Bermuda's parishes were attached to the [See of Nova
Scotia](/wiki/Diocese_of_Nova_Scotia_and_Prince_Edward_Island "Diocese of Nova
Scotia and Prince Edward Island"). Bermuda was then grouped into the new
Diocese of Newfoundland and Bermuda from 1839. In 1879, the Synod of the
Church of England in Bermuda was formed. At the same time, a Diocese of
Bermuda became separate from the [Diocese of
Newfoundland](/wiki/Diocese_of_Newfoundland "Diocese of Newfoundland"), but
both continued to be grouped under the _Bishop of Newfoundland and Bermuda_
until 1919, when Newfoundland and Bermuda each received its own Bishop.

The Church of England in Bermuda was renamed in 1978 as the [Anglican Church
of Bermuda](/wiki/Anglican_Church_of_Bermuda "Anglican Church of Bermuda"),
which is an [extra-provincial diocese](/wiki/Extra-
provincial_Anglican_churches "Extra-provincial Anglican churches"),[21] with
both [metropolitan](/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop "Metropolitan bishop") and
[primatial](/wiki/Primate_\(bishop\) "Primate \(bishop\)") authority coming
directly from the Archbishop of Canterbury. Among its parish churches is [St
Peter's Church](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Church,_St._George%27s "St. Peter's
Church, St. George's") in the [UNESCO World Heritage
Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site") of [St
George's Town](/wiki/St._George%27s,_Bermuda "St. George's, Bermuda"), which
is both the oldest Anglican and the oldest non-Roman Catholic church in the
New World.

### 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 21st century")]

#### Deposition from holy orders
overturned[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Deposition from holy orders overturned")]

Under the guidance of [Rowan Williams](/wiki/Rowan_Williams "Rowan Williams")
and with significant pressure from clergy union representatives, the
ecclesiastical penalty for convicted felons to be defrocked was set aside from
the [Clergy Discipline Measure 2003](/wiki/List_of_Church_of_England_Measures
"List of Church of England Measures"). The clergy union argued that the
penalty was unfair to victims of hypothetical miscarriages of criminal
justice, because the ecclesiastical penalty is considered irreversible.
Although clerics can still be banned for life from ministry, they remain
ordained as priests.[22]

#### Dwindling
congregations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Dwindling congregations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Holy_trinity_front_8809.jpg/220px-
Holy_trinity_front_8809.jpg)](/wiki/File:Holy_trinity_front_8809.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Holy_trinity_front_8809.jpg "Enlarge")

One of the now "redundant" buildings, [Holy Trinity Church,
Wensley](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Church,_Wensley "Holy Trinity Church, Wensley"),
in North Yorkshire; much of the current structure was built in the 14th and
15th Centuries

The archbishops of [Canterbury](/wiki/Justin_Welby "Justin Welby") and
[York](/wiki/John_Sentamu "John Sentamu") warned in January 2015 that the
Church of England will no longer be able to carry on in its current form
unless the downward spiral in membership is somehow reversed as typical Sunday
attendances had halved to 800,000 in the previous 40 years:[23]

> The urgency of the challenge facing us is not in doubt. Attendance at Church
> of England services has declined at an average of one per cent per annum
> over recent decades and, in addition, the age profile of our membership has
> become significantly older than that of the population... Renewing and
> reforming aspects of our institutional life is a necessary but far from
> sufficient response to the challenges facing the Church of England... The
> age profile of our clergy has also been increasing. Around 40 per cent of
> parish clergy are due to retire over the next decade or so.

However, [Sarah Mullally](/wiki/Sarah_Mullally "Sarah Mullally"), the fourth
woman chosen to become a bishop in the Church of England, insisted in June
2015 that declining numbers at services should not necessarily be a cause of
despair for churches because people will still "encounter God" without ever
taking their place in a pew, saying that people might hear the Christian
message through social media sites such as Facebook or in a café run as a
community project.[24] Additionally, the church's own statistics reveal that
9.7 million people visit an Anglican church every year and 1 million students
are educated at Anglican schools (which number 4,700).[25]

Approximately 30 Church of England parish churches are declared "closed for
regular public worship" (previously termed "redundant") each year.[26] Between
1969 and 2010, a full 1795 closures were achieved, equalling roughly 11% of
the stock, with just over a third being [Listed
buildings](/wiki/Listed_buildings "Listed buildings"), either Grade I or II.
Of these, closures, only 514 were made since 1990. Some active use is made of
about half of the closed churches.[27]

#### Low
salaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Low salaries")]

In 2015 the Church of England admitted that it was embarrassed to be paying
staff under the living wage. The Church of England had previously campaigned
for all employers to pay this minimum amount. The archbishop of Canterbury
acknowledged it was not the only area where the church "fell short of its
standards".[28]

## Doctrine and
practice[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Doctrine and practice")]

See also: [Anglicanism](/wiki/Anglicanism "Anglicanism") and [Anglican
doctrine](/wiki/Anglican_doctrine "Anglican doctrine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Hooker-
Statue.jpeg/220px-Hooker-Statue.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Hooker-Statue.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Hooker-Statue.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Richard Hooker](/wiki/Richard_Hooker_\(theologian\) "Richard Hooker
\(theologian\)") (1554–1600), one of the most influential figures in shaping
Anglican theology and self-identity

The [canon law](/wiki/Canon_law "Canon law") of the Church of England
identifies the [Christian scriptures](/wiki/Bible "Bible") as the source of
its doctrine. In addition, doctrine is also derived from the teachings of the
[Church Fathers](/wiki/Church_Fathers "Church Fathers") and [ecumenical
councils](/wiki/Ecumenical_councils "Ecumenical councils") (as well as the
[ecumenical creeds](/wiki/Ecumenical_creeds "Ecumenical creeds")) in so far as
these agree with scripture. This doctrine is expressed in the [Thirty-Nine
Articles of Religion](/wiki/Thirty-Nine_Articles_of_Religion "Thirty-Nine
Articles of Religion"), the [Book of Common
Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer "Book of Common Prayer"), and the Ordinal
containing the rites for the ordination of [deacons](/wiki/Deacon#Anglicanism
"Deacon"), [priests](/wiki/Anglican_priest "Anglican priest"), and the
consecration of bishops.[29] Unlike other traditions, the Church of England
has no single theologian that it can look to as a founder. However, [Richard
Hooker](/wiki/Richard_Hooker "Richard Hooker")'s appeal to scripture, [church
tradition](/wiki/Christian_tradition "Christian tradition"), and
[reason](/wiki/Reason "Reason") as sources of authority continue to inform
Anglican identity.[30]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Canterbury_Cathedral_-
_Portal_Nave_Cross-spire.jpeg/220px-Canterbury_Cathedral_-_Portal_Nave_Cross-
spire.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Canterbury_Cathedral_-_Portal_Nave_Cross-spire.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Canterbury_Cathedral_-_Portal_Nave_Cross-spire.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Canterbury Cathedral](/wiki/Canterbury_Cathedral "Canterbury Cathedral")
houses the _[cathedra](/wiki/Cathedra "Cathedra")_ or episcopal chair of the
[Archbishop of Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of
Canterbury") and is the cathedral of the [Diocese of
Canterbury](/wiki/Diocese_of_Canterbury "Diocese of Canterbury") and the
[mother church](/wiki/Mother_church "Mother church") of the Church of England
as well as a focus for the [Anglican Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion
"Anglican Communion")

The Church of England's doctrinal character today is largely the result of the
Elizabethan Settlement, which sought to establish a comprehensive middle way
between Roman Catholicism and Protestantism. The Church of England affirms the
Protestant Reformation principle that scripture contains all things necessary
to salvation and is the final arbiter in doctrinal matters. The Thirty-nine
Articles are the church's only official confessional statement. Though not a
complete system of doctrine, the articles highlight areas of agreement with
[Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheran "Lutheran") and [Reformed](/wiki/Calvinism
"Calvinism") positions, while differentiating Anglicanism from Roman
Catholicism and [Anabaptism](/wiki/Anabaptism "Anabaptism").[30]

While embracing some themes of the Protestant Reformation, the Church of
England also maintains Catholic traditions of the ancient church and teachings
of the Church Fathers, unless these are considered contrary to scripture. It
accepts the decisions of the first four ecumenical councils concerning the
[Trinity](/wiki/Trinity "Trinity") and the
[Incarnation](/wiki/Incarnation_\(Christianity\) "Incarnation
\(Christianity\)"). The Church of England also preserves Catholic Order by
adhering to [episcopal polity](/wiki/Episcopal_polity "Episcopal polity"),
with ordained orders of bishops, priests and deacons. There are differences of
opinion within the Church of England over the necessity of episcopacy. Some
consider it essential, while others feel it is needed for the proper ordering
of the church.[30] In sum these express the 'Via Media' viewpoint that the
first five centuries of doctrinal development and church order as approved as
acceptable be a kind of yardstick by which to gauge authentic catholicity, as
minimum and sufficient; Anglicanism did not emerge as the result of
charismatic leaders with particular doctrines. It is light on details compared
to Roman Catholic, Reformed and Lutheran teachings. The Bible, the Creeds,
Apostolic Order, and the administration of the Sacraments are sufficient to
establish Catholicity. Indeed, not one major doctrinal development emerged
from the English reformation, Diarmid MacCulloch, The Later Reformation in
England, 1990, p. 55. The Reformation in England was initially much concerned
about doctrine but the Elizabethan Settlement tried to put a stop to doctrinal
contentions. The proponents of further changes, nonetheless, tried to get
their way by making changes in Church Order (abolition of bishops), governance
(Canon Law) and liturgy ('too Catholic'). They did not succeed because the
Monarchy, the Church and resisted and the majority of the population were
indifferent. Moreover, "despite all the assumptions of the Reformation
founders of that Church, it had retained a catholic character." The
Elizabethan Settlement had created a cuckoo in a nest..." a Protestant
theology and program within a largely pre-Reformation Catholic structure whose
continuing life would arouse a theological interest in the Catholicism that
had created it; and would result in the rejection of predestinarian theology
in favor of sacraments, especially the eucharist, ceremonial, and anti-
Calvinist doctrine" (ibid pp. 78–86). The existence of cathedrals "without
substantial alteration" and "where the "old devotional world cast its longest
shadow for the future of the ethos that would become Anglicanism," p. 79. This
is "One of the great mysteries of the English Reformation," ibid that there
was no complete break with the past but a muddle that was per force turned
into a virtue. The story of the English Reformation is the tale of retreat
from the Protestant advance of 1550 which could not proceed further in the
face of the opposition of the institution which was rooted in the medieval
past, ibid. p. 142 and the adamant opposition of Queen Elizabeth I.

The Church of England has, as one of its distinguishing marks, a breadth and
"open-mindedness". This tolerance has allowed Anglicans who emphasise the
Catholic tradition and others who emphasise the Reformed tradition to coexist.
The three "parties" (see [Churchmanship](/wiki/Churchmanship "Churchmanship"))
in the Church of England are sometimes called [high church](/wiki/High_church
"High church") (or [Anglo-Catholic](/wiki/Anglo-Catholic "Anglo-Catholic")),
[low church](/wiki/Low_church "Low church") (or [evangelical
Anglican](/wiki/Evangelical_Anglican "Evangelical Anglican")) and [broad
church](/wiki/Broad_church "Broad church") (or
[liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Christianity "Liberal Christianity")). The high church
party places importance on the Church of England's continuity with the pre-
Reformation Catholic Church, adherence to ancient liturgical usages and the
sacerdotal nature of the priesthood. As their name suggests, Anglo-Catholics
maintain many traditional Catholic practices and liturgical forms.[31] The low
church party is more Protestant in both ceremony and theology.[32]
Historically, broad church has been used to describe those of middle-of-the-
road ceremonial preferences who lean theologically towards liberal
Protestantism.[33] The balance between these strands of churchmanship is not
static: in 2013, 40% of Church of England worshippers attended evangelical
churches (compared with 26% in 1989), and 83% of very large congregations were
evangelical. Such churches were also reported to attract higher numbers of men
and young adults than others.[34]

### Worship and
liturgy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Worship and liturgy")]

The Church of England's official book of liturgy as established in English Law
is the _[Book of Common Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer "Book of Common
Prayer")_. In addition to this book the General Synod has also legislated for
a modern [liturgical book](/wiki/Liturgical_book "Liturgical book"), _[Common
Worship](/wiki/Common_Worship "Common Worship")_ , dating from 2000, which can
be used as an alternative to the BCP. Like its predecessor, the 1980
_[Alternative Service Book](/wiki/Alternative_Service_Book "Alternative
Service Book")_ , it differs from the _Book of Common Prayer_ in providing a
range of alternative services, mostly in modern language, although it does
include some BCP-based forms as well, for example Order Two for Holy
Communion. (This is a revision of the BCP service, altering some words and
allowing the insertion of some other liturgical texts such as the _[Agnus
Dei](/wiki/Agnus_Dei_\(liturgy\) "Agnus Dei \(liturgy\)")_ before communion.)
The Order One rite follows the pattern of more modern liturgical scholarship.

The liturgies are organised according to the traditional [liturgical
year](/wiki/Liturgical_year "Liturgical year") and the [calendar of
saints](/wiki/Calendar_of_saints_\(Church_of_England\) "Calendar of saints
\(Church of England\)"). The [sacraments](/wiki/Anglican_sacraments "Anglican
sacraments") of [baptism](/wiki/Baptism "Baptism") and the
[Eucharist](/wiki/Eucharist "Eucharist") are generally thought necessary to
salvation. [Infant baptism](/wiki/Infant_baptism "Infant baptism") is
practised. At a later age, individuals baptised as infants receive
[confirmation](/wiki/Confirmation "Confirmation") by a bishop, at which time
they reaffirm the baptismal promises made by their parents or sponsors. The
Eucharist, consecrated by a thanksgiving prayer including Christ's [Words of
Institution](/wiki/Words_of_Institution "Words of Institution"), is believed
to be "a memorial of Christ's once-for-all redemptive acts in which Christ is
objectively present and effectually received in faith".[35]

The use of hymns and [music in the Church of
England](/wiki/Anglican_church_music "Anglican church music") has changed
dramatically over the centuries. Traditional [Choral
evensong](/wiki/Evening_Prayer_\(Anglican\) "Evening Prayer \(Anglican\)") is
a staple of most cathedrals.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
style of [psalm](/wiki/Psalm "Psalm") chanting harks back to the Church of
England's pre-reformation roots. During the 18th century, clergy such as
[Charles Wesley](/wiki/Charles_Wesley "Charles Wesley") introduced their own
styles of worship with poetic hymns.

In the latter half of the 20th century, the influence of the [Charismatic
Movement](/wiki/Charismatic_Movement "Charismatic Movement") significantly
altered the worship traditions of numerous Church of England parishes,
primarily affecting those of [evangelical](/wiki/Evangelical "Evangelical")
persuasion. These churches now adopt a [contemporary
worship](/wiki/Contemporary_worship "Contemporary worship") form of service,
with minimal liturgical or ritual elements, and incorporating [contemporary
worship music](/wiki/Contemporary_worship_music "Contemporary worship music").

### Women's
ministry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Women's ministry")]

Women were appointed as deaconesses from 1861 but they could not function
fully as deacons and were not considered ordained clergy. Women have been [lay
readers](/wiki/Lay_reader "Lay reader") for a long time. During the First
World War, some women were appointed as lay readers, known as "[bishop's
messengers](/wiki/Bishop%27s_messenger "Bishop's messenger")", who also led
missions and ran churches in the absence of men. After that no more lay
readers were appointed until 1969.

Legislation authorising the ordination of women as deacons was passed in 1986
and they were first ordained in 1987. The [ordination of
women](/wiki/Ordination_of_women "Ordination of women") as priests was passed
by the [General Synod](/wiki/General_Synod_of_the_Church_of_England "General
Synod of the Church of England") in 1992 and [began in
1994](/wiki/List_of_the_first_32_women_ordained_as_Church_of_England_priests
"List of the first 32 women ordained as Church of England priests"). In 2010,
for the first time in the history of the Church of England, more women than
men were ordained as priests (290 women and 273 men).[36]

In July 2005, the synod voted to "set in train" the process of allowing the
consecration of women as bishops. In February 2006, the synod voted
overwhelmingly for the "further exploration" of possible arrangements for
parishes that did not want to be directly under the authority of a bishop who
is a woman.[37] On 7 July 2008, the synod voted to approve the ordination of
women as bishops and rejected moves for alternative episcopal oversight for
those who do not accept the ministry of bishops who are women.[38] Actual
ordinations of women to the episcopate required further legislation, which was
narrowly rejected in a vote at General Synod in November 2012.[39][40]

On 20 November 2013, the General Synod voted overwhelmingly in support of a
plan to allow the ordination of women as bishops, with 378 in favour, 8
against and 25 abstentions.[41]

On 14 July 2014, the General Synod approved the ordination of women as
bishops. The House of Bishops recorded 37 votes in favour, two against with
one abstention. The House of Clergy had 162 in favour, 25 against and four
abstentions. The House of Laity voted 152 for, 45 against with five
abstentions.[42] This legislation had to be approved by the Ecclesiastical
Committee of the Parliament before it could be finally implemented at the
November 2014 synod.

In December 2014, [Libby Lane](/wiki/Libby_Lane "Libby Lane") was announced as
the first woman to become a bishop in the Church of England. She was
consecrated as a bishop in January 2015.[43] [44]

In July 2015, [Rachel Treweek](/wiki/Rachel_Treweek "Rachel Treweek") was the
first woman to become a diocesan bishop in the Church of England when she
became the [Bishop of Gloucester](/wiki/Bishop_of_Gloucester "Bishop of
Gloucester").[45] She and [Sarah Mullally](/wiki/Sarah_Mullally "Sarah
Mullally"), Bishop of Crediton, were the first women to be ordained as bishops
at [Canterbury Cathedral](/wiki/Canterbury_Cathedral "Canterbury
Cathedral").[45] Treweek later made headlines by calling for gender-inclusive
language, saying that "God is not to be seen as male. God is God."[46]

In May 2018, the Diocese of London consecrated [Dame Sarah
Mullally](/wiki/Dame_Sarah_Mullally "Dame Sarah Mullally") as the first woman
to serve as the [Bishop of London](/wiki/Bishop_of_London "Bishop of
London").[47] Bishop Sarah Mullally occupies the third most senior position in
the Anglican church.[48] Mullally has described herself as a feminist and will
ordain both men and women to the priesthood.[49] She is also considered by
some to be a theological liberal.[50] On women's [reproductive
rights](/wiki/Reproductive_rights "Reproductive rights"), Mullally describes
herself as [pro-choice](/wiki/Abortion-rights_movements "Abortion-rights
movements") while also being personally [pro-life](/wiki/Anti-
abortion_movements "Anti-abortion movements").[51] On marriage, she supports
the current stance of the Church of England that marriage is between a man and
a woman, but also said that "It is a time for us to reflect on our tradition
and scripture, and together say how we can offer a response that is about it
being inclusive love.”[52]

After the consecration of the first women as bishops, [Women and the
Church](/wiki/Women_and_the_Church "Women and the Church") (WATCH), a group
supporting the ministries of women in the Church of England, called for
language referring to God as "Mother".[53] This call for more gender inclusive
language has receive the outspoken support of the Rt Rev Alan Wilson, the
Bishop of Buckingham.[54] In 2015, the Rev Jody Stowell, from WATCH, expressed
her support for female images saying "we're not restricted to understanding
God with one gender. I would encourage people to explore those kinds of
images. They're wholly Biblical."[55]

### Same-sex unions and LGBT
clergy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Same-sex unions and LGBT clergy")]

See also: [Same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage_in_the_United_Kingdom "Same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom"),
[LGBT rights in the United Kingdom](/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_the_United_Kingdom
"LGBT rights in the United Kingdom"), and [Homosexuality and the Anglican
Communion](/wiki/Homosexuality_and_the_Anglican_Communion "Homosexuality and
the Anglican Communion")

The Church of England has been discussing [same-sex marriages](/wiki/Same-
sex_marriage_in_the_United_Kingdom "Same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom")
and LGBT clergy.[56] "The Church of England does not allow gay weddings, but
its priests are allowed to be in a [civil partnership](/wiki/Civil_union
"Civil union")." The church holds that marriage is a union of one man with one
woman.[57] However, the church teaches "Same-sex relationships often embody
genuine mutuality and fidelity."[58] The church also officially supports
[civil partnerships](/wiki/Civil_partnerships "Civil partnerships"); "We
believe that Civil Partnerships still have a place, including for some
Christian [LGBTI](/wiki/Intersex_and_LGBT "Intersex and LGBT") couples who see
them as a way of gaining legal recognition of their relationship."[59] The
"Church of England does not conduct Civil Partnership Ceremonies or Same Sex
Marriages but individual churches can conduct a service of thanksgiving after
a ceremony."[60] The church says "clergy in the Church of England are
permitted to offer prayers of support on a pastoral basis for people in same-
sex relationships;"[61] As such, many Anglican churches, with clergy open to
it, "already bless same-sex couples on an unofficial basis."[62][63]

[Civil Partnerships](/wiki/Civil_partnership_in_the_United_Kingdom "Civil
partnership in the United Kingdom") for clergy have been allowed since
2005.[64][65] The church extends pensions to clergy in [civil
unions](/wiki/Civil_union "Civil union").[66] In a missive to clergy, the
church communicated that "there was a need for committed same-sex couples to
be given recognition and 'compassionate attention' from the Church, including
special prayers."[67] "There is no prohibition on prayers’ being said in
church or there being a 'service'" after a civil union.[68] After same-sex
marriage was legalised, the church asked for the government to continue to
offer civil unions saying "The Church of England recognises that same-sex
relationships often embody fidelity and mutuality. Civil partnerships enable
these Christian virtues to be recognised socially and legally in a proper
framework."[69]

In 2014, the Bishops released guidelines that permit "more informal kind of
prayer" for couples.[70] In the guidelines, "gay couples who get married will
be able to ask for special prayers in the Church of England after their
wedding, the bishops have agreed."[71] In 2016, The Bishop of Grantham, the Rt
Rev [Nicholas Chamberlain](/wiki/Nicholas_Chamberlain "Nicholas Chamberlain"),
announced he is gay, in a same-sex relationship and celibate; becoming the
first bishop to do so in the church.[72] The church had decided in 2013 that
gay clergy in [civil partnerships](/wiki/Civil_union "Civil union") could
become bishops.[65][73] “The House [of Bishops] has confirmed that clergy in
civil partnerships, and living in accordance with the teaching of the church
on human sexuality, can be considered as candidates for the episcopate."[74]

In 2017, the House of Clergy voted against the motion to 'take note' of the
Bishops' report defining marriage as between a man and a woman.[75] Due to
passage in all three houses being required, the motion was rejected.[76] After
General Synod rejected the motion, the Archbishops of Canterbury and York
called for "radical new Christian inclusion" that is "based on good, healthy,
flourishing relationships, and in a proper 21st century understanding of being
human and of being sexual."[77] The church officially opposes
'[conversion](/wiki/Conversion_therapy "Conversion therapy")' therapy, a
practice which attempts to change a gay or lesbian person's sexual
orientation, calling it unethical and supports the
[banning](/wiki/Conversion_therapy_ban "Conversion therapy ban") of
'conversion' therapy in the UK.[78][79] The [Diocese of
Hereford](/wiki/Diocese_of_Hereford "Diocese of Hereford") approved a motion
calling for the church "to create a set of formal services and prayers to
bless those who have had a same-sex marriage or civil partnership."[80]

Regarding [transgender issues](/wiki/Christianity_and_transgender_people
"Christianity and transgender people"), the 2017 General Synod voted in favour
of a motion saying that transgender people should be “welcomed and affirmed in
their parish church...”[81][82] The motion also asked the Bishops "to look
into special services for transgender people."[83][84] The House of Bishops
declined to create a new liturgy, but advised that clergy adapt the service
for an affirmation of baptism to mark a gender transition.[85][86] "The House
notes that the Affirmation of Baptismal Faith, found in _Common Worship_ , is
an ideal liturgical rite which trans people can use to mark this moment of
personal renewal."[87] Transgender people may marry in the Church of England
after legally making a transition.[88] "Since the Gender Recognition Act
[2004], trans people legally confirmed in their gender identity under its
provisions are able to marry someone of the opposite sex in their parish
church."[89] Since 2000, the church has allowed priests to undergo gender
transition and remain in office.[90] The church has ordained openly
transgender clergy since 2005.[91]

### Liberal
theology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Liberal theology")]

See also: [Liberal Christianity](/wiki/Liberal_Christianity "Liberal
Christianity")

Just as the Church of England has a large conservative or "traditionalist"
wing, it also has many [liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Christianity "Liberal
Christianity") members and clergy. Approximately one third of clergy "doubt or
disbelieve in the physical resurrection".[92] Others, such as the Revd [Giles
Fraser](/wiki/Giles_Fraser "Giles Fraser"), a contributor to _The Guardian_ ,
have argued for an allegorical interpretation of the [virgin birth of
Jesus](/wiki/Virgin_birth_of_Jesus "Virgin birth of Jesus").[93] _The
Independent_ reported in 2014 that, according to a YouGov survey of Church of
England clergy, "as many as 16 per cent are unclear about God and two per cent
think it is no more than a human construct."[94][95] Moreover, many
congregations are seeker-friendly environments. For example, one report from
the [Church Mission Society](/wiki/Church_Mission_Society "Church Mission
Society") suggested that the church open up "a pagan church where Christianity
[is] very much in the centre" to reach out to spiritual people.[96]

### Bioethics
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Bioethics issues")]

The Church of England is generally opposed to abortion but recognises that
"there can be - strictly limited - conditions under which it may be morally
preferable to any available alternative".[97] The church also opposes
euthanasia. Its official stance is that "While acknowledging the complexity of
the issues involved in assisted dying/suicide and voluntary euthanasia, the
Church of England is opposed to any change in the law or in medical practice
that would make assisted dying/suicide or voluntary euthanasia permissible in
law or acceptable in practice." It also states that "Equally, the Church
shares the desire to alleviate physical and psychological suffering, but
believes that assisted dying/suicide and voluntary euthanasia are not
acceptable means of achieving these laudable goals."[98] However, George
Carey, a former Archbishop of Canterbury, announced that he had changed his
stance on euthanasia in 2014 and now advocated legalising "assisted
dying".[99] On embryonic stem-cell research, the church has announced
"cautious acceptance to the proposal to produce cytoplasmic hybrid embryos for
research".[100]

## Poverty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Poverty")]

### Church Urban
Fund[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Church Urban Fund")]

Main article: [Church Urban Fund](/wiki/Church_Urban_Fund "Church Urban Fund")

The Church of England set up the [Church Urban Fund](/wiki/Church_Urban_Fund
"Church Urban Fund") in the 1980s to tackle poverty and
[deprivation](/wiki/Social_deprivation "Social deprivation"). They see poverty
as trapping individuals and communities with some people in urgent need. This
leads to [dependency](/wiki/Dependant "Dependant"),
[homelessness](/wiki/Homelessness "Homelessness"), [hunger](/wiki/Hunger
"Hunger"), [isolation](/wiki/Social_isolation "Social isolation"), [low
income](/wiki/Low_income "Low income"), [mental health](/wiki/Mental_health
"Mental health") problems, [social exclusion](/wiki/Social_exclusion "Social
exclusion") and violence. They feel that poverty reduces confidence and [life
expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") and that people born in
poor conditions have difficulty escaping their disadvantaged
circumstances.[101]

#### Child
poverty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Child poverty")]

In parts of [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool"), Manchester and
[Newcastle](/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne "Newcastle upon Tyne") two-thirds of
babies are born to poverty and have poorer life chances, also life expectancy
15 years lower than babies born in most fortunate communities. [South Shore,
Blackpool](/wiki/South_Shore,_Blackpool "South Shore, Blackpool"), has lowest
life expectancy at 66 years for men.[102]

> The deep-rooted unfairness in our society is highlighted by these stark
> statistics. Children being born in this country, just a few miles apart,
> couldn't witness a more wildly differing start to life. In child poverty
> terms, we live in one of the most unequal countries in the western world. We
> want people to understand where their own community sits alongside
> neighbouring communities. The disparity is often shocking but it's crucial
> that, through greater awareness, people from all backgrounds come together
> to think about what could be done to support those born into poverty. [Paul
> Hackwood, the Chair of Trustees at Church Urban Fund][103]

### Action on
hunger[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Action on hunger")]

Many prominent people in the Church of England have spoken out against poverty
and welfare cuts in the United Kingdom. Twenty-seven bishops are among 43
Christian leaders who signed a letter which urged [David
Cameron](/wiki/David_Cameron "David Cameron") to make sure people [have enough
to eat](/wiki/Poverty#Hunger "Poverty").

> We often hear talk of hard choices. Surely few can be harder than that faced
> by the tens of thousands of older people who must 'heat or eat' each winter,
> harder than those faced by families whose wages have stayed flat while food
> prices have gone up 30% in just five years. Yet beyond even this we must, as
> a society, face up to the fact that over half of people using food banks
> have been put in that situation by cutbacks to and failures in the benefit
> system, whether it be payment delays or punitive sanctions.[104]

[Benefit](/wiki/Welfare_state_in_the_United_Kingdom "Welfare state in the
United Kingdom") cuts, failures and "punitive sanctions" force thousands of UK
citizens to use [food banks](/wiki/Food_bank "Food bank"). The campaign to end
hunger considers this "truly shocking" and called for a national day of
[fasting](/wiki/Fasting "Fasting") on 4 April 2014.[104]

##
Membership[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Membership")]

Official figures from 2005 showed there were 25 million baptised Anglicans in
England and Wales.[105] Due to its status as the
[established](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") church, in general,
anyone may be married, have their children baptised or their funeral in their
local [parish church](/wiki/Church_of_England_parish_church "Church of England
parish church"), regardless of whether they are baptised or regular
churchgoers.[106]

Between 1890 and 2001, churchgoing in the United Kingdom declined
steadily.[107] In the years 1968 to 1999, Anglican Sunday church attendances
almost halved, from 3.5 per cent of the population to 1.9 per cent.[108] By
the year 2014, Sunday church attendances had declined further to 1.4 per cent
of the population.[109] One study published in 2008 suggested that if current
trends were to continue, Sunday attendances could fall to 350,000 in 2030 and
just 87,800 in 2050.[110]

In 2011, the Church of England published statistics showing 1.7 million people
attending at least one of its services each month, a level maintained since
the turn of the millennium; approximately one million participating each
Sunday and three million taking part in a Church of England service on
Christmas Day or Christmas Eve. The church also claimed that 30% attend Sunday
worship at least once a year; more than 40% attend a wedding in their local
church and still more attend a funeral there.[111] Nationally the Church of
England baptises one child in ten (2011).[112] In 2015, the church's
statistics showed that 2.6 million people attended a special Advent service,
2.4 million attended a Christmas service, 1.3 million attended an Easter
service, and 980,000 attended service during an average week.[113] In 2016,
2.6 million people attended a Christmas service, 1.2 million attended an
Easter service, 1.1 million people attended a service in the Church of England
each month, an average of 930,000 people attended a weekly service, an
additional 180,000 attended a service for school each week, and an average of
740,000 people attended Sunday service.[114]

The Church of England has 18,000 active ordained clergy and 10,000 licensed
lay ministers.[115] In 2009, 491 people were recommended for ordination
training, maintaining the level at the turn of the millennium, and 564 new
clergy (266 women and 298 men) were ordained. More than half of those ordained
(193 men and 116 women) were appointed to full-time paid ministry.[116] In
2011, 504 new clergy were ordained, including 264 to paid ministry, and 349
[lay readers](/wiki/Lay_reader "Lay reader") were admitted to ministry; and
the mode age-range of those recommended for ordination training had remained
40–49 since 1999.[117]

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Structure")]

See also: [Anglican ministry](/wiki/Anglican_ministry "Anglican ministry") and
[List of Church of England dioceses](/wiki/List_of_Church_of_England_dioceses
"List of Church of England dioceses")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Dioceses_of_Church_of_England.svg/220px-
Dioceses_of_Church_of_England.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Dioceses_of_Church_of_England.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Dioceses_of_Church_of_England.svg "Enlarge")

Dioceses of the Church of England

[Province of Canterbury](/wiki/Province_of_Canterbury "Province of
Canterbury")

[Province of York](/wiki/Province_of_York "Province of York")

Article XIX ('Of the Church') of the 39 Articles defines the church as
follows:

> The [visible Church of Christ](/wiki/Church_visible "Church visible") is a
> congregation of faithful men, in which [the pure Word of God is preached,
> and the sacraments be duly ministered](/wiki/Marks_of_the_Church "Marks of
> the Church") according to Christ's ordinance in all those things that of
> necessity are requisite to the same.[118]

[The British monarch](/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom "Monarchy of the
United Kingdom") has the constitutional title of [Supreme Governor of the
Church of England](/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England "Supreme
Governor of the Church of England"). The canon law of the Church of England
states, "We acknowledge that the Queen's most excellent Majesty, acting
according to the laws of the realm, is the highest power under God in this
kingdom, and has supreme authority over all persons in all causes, as well
ecclesiastical as civil."[119] In practice this power is often exercised
through [Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the
United Kingdom") and the [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the
United Kingdom").

The [Church of Ireland](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland "Church of Ireland") and the
[Church in Wales](/wiki/Church_in_Wales "Church in Wales") separated from the
Church of England in 1869[120] and 1920[121] respectively and are autonomous
churches in the Anglican Communion; Scotland's national church, the [Church of
Scotland](/wiki/Church_of_Scotland "Church of Scotland"), is
[Presbyterian](/wiki/Presbyterianism "Presbyterianism") but the [Scottish
Episcopal Church](/wiki/Scottish_Episcopal_Church "Scottish Episcopal Church")
is in the Anglican Communion.[122]

In addition to England, the jurisdiction of the Church of England extends to
the [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"), the [Channel
Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") and a few parishes in
[Flintshire](/wiki/Flintshire "Flintshire"),
[Monmouthshire](/wiki/Monmouthshire "Monmouthshire"), [Powys](/wiki/Powys
"Powys") and [Radnorshire](/wiki/Radnorshire "Radnorshire") in Wales [which
voted to remain with the Church of England rather than joining the Church in
Wales](/wiki/Church_of_England_border_polls_1915%E2%80%931916 "Church of
England border polls 1915–1916").[123] Expatriate congregations on the
continent of Europe have become the [Diocese of Gibraltar in
Europe](/wiki/Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe "Diocese of Gibraltar in
Europe").

The church is structured as follows (from the lowest level upwards):

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/TootBaldon_StLawrence_ParishChurch.JPG/220px-
TootBaldon_StLawrence_ParishChurch.JPG)](/wiki/File:TootBaldon_StLawrence_ParishChurch.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:TootBaldon_StLawrence_ParishChurch.JPG "Enlarge")

The parish church of St Lawrence in [Toot Baldon](/wiki/Toot_Baldon "Toot
Baldon") is typical of many small English village churches

  * [Parish](/wiki/Parish "Parish") is the most local level, often consisting of one church building and community, although many parishes are joining forces in a variety of ways for financial reasons. The parish is looked after by a parish [priest](/wiki/Anglican_priest "Anglican priest") who for historical or legal reasons may be called by one of the following offices: [vicar](/wiki/Vicar "Vicar"), [rector](/wiki/Rector_\(ecclesiastical\) "Rector \(ecclesiastical\)"), [priest in charge](/wiki/Priest_in_charge "Priest in charge"), team rector, team vicar. The first, second, and fourth of these may also be known as the 'incumbent'. The running of the parish is the joint responsibility of the incumbent and the [Parochial Church Council](/wiki/Parochial_Church_Council "Parochial Church Council") (PCC), which consists of the parish clergy and elected representatives from the congregation. The Diocese of Gibraltar in Europe is not formally divided into parishes.
  * There are a number of local churches that do not have a parish. In urban areas there are a number of [proprietary chapels](/wiki/Proprietary_chapel "Proprietary chapel") (mostly built in the 19th century to cope with urbanisation and growth in population). Also in more recent years there are increasingly [church plants](/wiki/Church_plant "Church plant") and [fresh expressions](/wiki/Fresh_expression "Fresh expression") of church, whereby new congregations are planted in locations such as schools or pubs to spread the Gospel of Christ in non-traditional ways.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe.PNG/220px-
Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe.PNG)](/wiki/File:Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe.PNG "Enlarge")

Map showing the Diocese of Gibraltar in Europe with the archdeaconries colour-
coded

  * [Deanery](/wiki/Deanery "Deanery"), _e.g._ , Lewisham or Runnymede. This is the area for which a [Rural Dean](/wiki/Rural_Dean "Rural Dean") (or area dean) is responsible. It consists of a number of parishes in a particular district. The rural dean is usually the incumbent of one of the constituent parishes. The parishes each elect lay (non-ordained) representatives to the deanery [synod](/wiki/Synod "Synod"). Deanery synod members each have a vote in the election of representatives to the diocesan synod.
  * Archdeaconry, _e.g._ , the seven in the [Diocese of Gibraltar in Europe](/wiki/Diocese_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe "Diocese of Gibraltar in Europe"). This is the area under the jurisdiction of an [archdeacon](/wiki/Archdeacon "Archdeacon"). It consists of a number of deaneries.
  * [Diocese](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese"), _e.g._ , [Diocese of Durham](/wiki/Diocese_of_Durham "Diocese of Durham"), [Diocese of Guildford](/wiki/Diocese_of_Guildford "Diocese of Guildford"), [Diocese of St Albans](/wiki/Diocese_of_St_Albans "Diocese of St Albans"). This is the area under the jurisdiction of a diocesan bishop, _e.g._ , the Bishops of Durham, Guildford and St Albans, and will have a cathedral. There may be one or more assisting bishops, usually called [suffragan bishops](/wiki/Suffragan_bishop "Suffragan bishop"), within the diocese who assist the diocesan bishop in his ministry, _e.g._ , in Guildford diocese, the Bishop of Dorking. In some very large dioceses a legal measure has been enacted to create "episcopal areas", where the diocesan bishop runs one such area himself and appoints "area bishops" to run the other areas as mini-dioceses, legally delegating many of his powers to the area bishops. Dioceses with episcopal areas include [London](/wiki/Diocese_of_London "Diocese of London"), [Chelmsford](/wiki/Diocese_of_Chelmsford "Diocese of Chelmsford"), [Oxford](/wiki/Diocese_of_Oxford "Diocese of Oxford"), [Chichester](/wiki/Diocese_of_Chichester "Diocese of Chichester"), [Southwark](/wiki/Anglican_Diocese_of_Southwark "Anglican Diocese of Southwark"), and [Lichfield](/wiki/Diocese_of_Lichfield "Diocese of Lichfield"). The bishops work with an elected body of [lay](/wiki/Laity "Laity") and [ordained](/wiki/Ordained "Ordained") representatives, known as the [Diocesan Synod](/wiki/Diocesan_Synod "Diocesan Synod"), to run the diocese. A diocese is subdivided into a number of archdeaconries.
  * [Province](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_province "Ecclesiastical province"), _i.e._ , Canterbury or York. This is the area under the jurisdiction of an [archbishop](/wiki/Archbishop "Archbishop"), _i.e._ the Archbishops of Canterbury and York. Decision-making within the province is the responsibility of the [General Synod](/wiki/General_Synod "General Synod") (see also above). A province is subdivided into dioceses.
  * [Primacy](/wiki/Primacy_of_Canterbury "Primacy of Canterbury"), _i.e._ , Church of England. In addition to his specific authority in his own province, each archbishop is "Primate of All England" (Canterbury) or "Primate of England" (York) and has powers that extend over the whole country—for example his licence to marry without the [banns](/wiki/Banns "Banns") (marriage licence).
  * [Royal Peculiar](/wiki/Royal_Peculiar "Royal Peculiar"), a small number of churches more closely associated with [the Crown](/wiki/The_Crown "The Crown"), and a very few with the law and are outside the usual church hierarchy though conforming to the rite. These are outside episcopal jurisdiction.

All [rectors and vicars](/wiki/Vicar#Anglican "Vicar") are [appointed by
patrons](/wiki/Advowson "Advowson"), who may be private individuals, corporate
bodies such as cathedrals, colleges or trusts, or by the bishop or directly by
the Crown. No clergy can be instituted and inducted into a parish without
swearing the Oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty, and taking the Oath of
Canonical Obedience "in all things lawful and honest" to the bishop. Usually
they are instituted to the benefice by the bishop and then inducted by the
archdeacon into the possession of the benefice property—church and parsonage.
[Curates](/wiki/Curate "Curate") (assistant clergy) are appointed by rectors
and vicars, or if priests-in-charge by the bishop after consultation with the
patron. Cathedral clergy (normally a
[dean](/wiki/List_of_deans_in_the_Church_of_England "List of deans in the
Church of England") and a varying number of residentiary canons who constitute
the cathedral chapter) are appointed either by the Crown, the bishop, or by
the dean and chapter themselves. Clergy officiate in a diocese either because
they hold office as beneficed clergy or are licensed by the bishop when
appointed, or simply with permission.

###
Primates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Primates")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Justin_Welby_at_Seoul_Cathedral.jpg/180px-
Justin_Welby_at_Seoul_Cathedral.jpg)](/wiki/File:Justin_Welby_at_Seoul_Cathedral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Justin_Welby_at_Seoul_Cathedral.jpg "Enlarge")

[Justin Welby](/wiki/Justin_Welby "Justin Welby"), [Archbishop of
Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury")

The most senior bishop of the Church of England is the [Archbishop of
Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury"), who is
the [metropolitan](/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop "Metropolitan bishop") of the
southern province of England, the Province of Canterbury. He has the status of
[Primate](/wiki/Primate_\(bishop\) "Primate \(bishop\)") of All England. He is
the focus of unity for the worldwide Anglican Communion of independent
national or regional churches. [Justin Welby](/wiki/Justin_Welby "Justin
Welby") has been Archbishop of Canterbury since the confirmation of his
election on 4 February 2013.[124]

The second most senior bishop is the [Archbishop of
York](/wiki/Archbishop_of_York "Archbishop of York"), who is the metropolitan
of the northern province of England, the Province of York. For historical
reasons (relating to the time of York's control by the [Danes](/wiki/Danelaw
"Danelaw")) he is referred to as the Primate of England. [John
Sentamu](/wiki/John_Sentamu "John Sentamu") became Archbishop of York in 2005.
The Bishop of London, the Bishop of Durham and the Bishop of Winchester are
ranked in the next three positions.

### Diocesan
bishops[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Diocesan bishops")]

The process of appointing diocesan bishops is complex, due to historical
reasons balancing hierarchy against democracy, and is handled by the [Crown
Nominations Committee](/wiki/Appointment_of_Church_of_England_bishops
"Appointment of Church of England bishops") which submits names to the Prime
Minister (acting on behalf of the Crown) for consideration.

### Representative
bodies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Representative bodies")]

Main article: [General Synod of the Church of
England](/wiki/General_Synod_of_the_Church_of_England "General Synod of the
Church of England")

The Church of England has a legislative body, the [General
Synod](/wiki/General_Synod_of_the_Church_of_England "General Synod of the
Church of England"). Synod can create two types of legislation,
[measures](/wiki/List_of_Church_of_England_Measures "List of Church of England
Measures") and [canons](/wiki/Canon_law "Canon law"). Measures have to be
approved but cannot be amended by the [British
Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United
Kingdom") before receiving the [Royal Assent](/wiki/Royal_Assent "Royal
Assent") and becoming part of the law of England.[125] Although it is the
[established](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") church in England only,
its measures must be approved by both Houses of Parliament including the non-
English members. Canons require Royal Licence and Royal Assent, but form the
law of the church, rather than the law of the land.[126]

Another assembly is the [Convocation of the English
Clergy](/wiki/Convocations_of_Canterbury_and_York "Convocations of Canterbury
and York"), which is older than the General Synod and its predecessor the
Church Assembly. By the 1969 Synodical Government Measure almost all of the
Convocations' functions were transferred to the General Synod. Additionally,
there are [Diocesan Synods](/wiki/Diocesan_Synod "Diocesan Synod") and
[deanery synods](/wiki/Deanery#Anglican_usage "Deanery"), which are the
governing bodies of the divisions of the Church.

### House of
Lords[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: House of Lords")]

Main article: [Lords Spiritual](/wiki/Lords_Spiritual "Lords Spiritual")

Of the 42 diocesan [archbishops](/wiki/Archbishop "Archbishop") and bishops in
the Church of England, 26 are permitted to sit in the [House of
Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of Lords"). The Archbishops of
[Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury") and
[York](/wiki/Archbishops_of_York "Archbishops of York") automatically have
seats, as do the Bishops of [London](/wiki/Bishop_of_London "Bishop of
London"), [Durham](/wiki/Bishop_of_Durham "Bishop of Durham") and
[Winchester](/wiki/Bishop_of_Winchester "Bishop of Winchester"). The remaining
21 seats are filled in order of seniority by [consecration](/wiki/Consecration
"Consecration"). It may take a diocesan bishop a number of years to reach the
House of Lords, at which point he becomes a [Lord
Spiritual](/wiki/Lords_Spiritual "Lords Spiritual"). The [Bishop of Sodor and
Man](/wiki/Bishop_of_Sodor_and_Man "Bishop of Sodor and Man") and the [Bishop
of Gibraltar in Europe](/wiki/Bishop_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe "Bishop of
Gibraltar in Europe") are not eligible to sit in the House of Lords as their
dioceses lie outside the United Kingdom.[127]

### Crown
dependencies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Crown dependencies")]

Although they are not part of [England](/wiki/England "England") or the
[United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the Church of England
is also the [Established Church](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") in the
[Crown dependencies](/wiki/Crown_dependencies "Crown dependencies") of the
[Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"), the [Bailiwick of
Jersey](/wiki/Jersey "Jersey") and the [Bailiwick of
Guernsey](/wiki/Bailiwick_of_Guernsey "Bailiwick of Guernsey"). The [Isle of
Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man") has its own diocese of [Sodor and
Man](/wiki/Sodor_and_Man "Sodor and Man"), and the [Bishop of Sodor and
Man](/wiki/Bishop_of_Sodor_and_Man "Bishop of Sodor and Man") is an ex officio
member of the [Legislative
Council](/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_the_Isle_of_Man "Legislative Council of
the Isle of Man") of the [Tynwald](/wiki/Tynwald "Tynwald") on the
island.[128] The [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands")
are part of the [Diocese of Winchester](/wiki/Diocese_of_Winchester "Diocese
of Winchester"), and in [Jersey](/wiki/Jersey "Jersey") the [Dean of
Jersey](/wiki/Dean_of_Jersey "Dean of Jersey") is a non-voting member of the
[States of Jersey](/wiki/States_of_Jersey "States of Jersey"). In
[Guernsey](/wiki/Guernsey "Guernsey") the Church of England is the
[Established Church](/wiki/State_religion "State religion"), although the
[Dean of Guernsey](/wiki/Dean_of_Guernsey "Dean of Guernsey") is not a member
of the [States of Guernsey](/wiki/States_of_Guernsey "States of
Guernsey").[129]

## Sex
abuse[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Sex abuse")]

See also: [Anglican Communion sexual abuse
cases](/wiki/Anglican_Communion_sexual_abuse_cases "Anglican Communion sexual
abuse cases")

The Archbishop of Canterbury, [Justin Welby](/wiki/Justin_Welby "Justin
Welby"), has made some effort to prevent complaints of [sex abuse
cases](/wiki/Anglican_Church_sexual_abuse_cases "Anglican Church sexual abuse
cases") being covered up. Independent investigators are examining files as far
back as the 1950s and Welby hopes this independence will prevent any
possibility of a [cover-up](/wiki/Cover-up "Cover-up").[130]

> We will systematically bring those transparently and openly first of all
> working with the survivors where they are still alive and then seeing what
> they want. The rule is survivors come first, not our own interests, and
> however important the person was, however distinguished, however well-known,
> survivors come first. (Justin Welby)

The personal files of all Anglican clergy since the 1950s are being audited in
an effort to ensure no cover-up. Welby emphasised repeatedly that no cover-up
would be acceptable.[131]

Despite such assurances there is concern that not enough may be done and
historic abuse may still sometimes be covered up. [Keith Porteous
Wood](/wiki/Keith_Porteous_Wood "Keith Porteous Wood") of the [National
Secular Society](/wiki/National_Secular_Society "National Secular Society")
stated:

> The problem wasn't that bishops weren't trained in such matters, it is the
> institutional culture of denial and the bullying of the abused and
> whistleblowers into silence. One report suggests that 13 bishops ignored
> letters written in the 1990s warning of abuse by Ball on behalf of a victim
> who later committed suicide. I have seen evidence that such bullying
> persists to this day. I hope that the Archbishop's review into the case of
> Peter Ball will deal with such bullying and what appears to be the undue
> influence exerted on the police and CPS by the Church in dealing with this
> case. The total failure of procedures, outlined by Ian Elliott, echoes that
> revealed in the totally damning Cahill Report about the conduct of the
> Archbishop Hope of York in respect of Robert Waddington. The current
> Archbishop of York has decided that this report should remain in printed
> form rather than be more widely available on the web.[132]

Bishop [Peter Ball](/wiki/Peter_Ball_\(bishop\) "Peter Ball \(bishop\)") was
convicted in October 2015 on several charges of indecent assault against young
adult men.[133] There are allegations of large-scale earlier cover-ups
involving many British establishment figures which prevented Ball's earlier
prosecution. There have also been allegations of [child sex
abuse](/wiki/Child_sex_abuse "Child sex abuse"), for example [Robert
Waddington](/wiki/Robert_Waddington#Allegations_of_abuse "Robert Waddington").
A complainant, known only as "Joe", tried for decades to have action taken
over sadistic sex abuse which Garth Moore perpetrated against him in 1976 when
"Joe" was 15 years old. None of the high ranking clergy who "Joe" spoke to
recall being told about the abuse, which "Joe" considers incredible.[134] A
representative of the solicitors firm representing "Joe" said:

> The Church of England wants to bury and discourage allegations of non-recent
> abuse. They know how difficult it is for survivors to come forward, and it
> appears from this case that the Church has a plan of making it hard for
> these vulnerable people to come forward. This survivor has had the courage
> to press his case. Most do not. Most harbour the psychological fallout in
> silence. We need to find a way to make the system more approachable for
> survivors.[135]

## Financial
situation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Financial situation")]

Main article: [Properties and finances of the Church of
England](/wiki/Properties_and_finances_of_the_Church_of_England "Properties
and finances of the Church of England")

Although an [established church](/wiki/Established_church "Established
church"), the Church of England does not receive any direct government
support. Donations comprise its largest source of income, and it also relies
heavily on the income from its various historic endowments. In 2005, the
Church of England had estimated total outgoings of around £900 million.[136]

The Church of England manages an [investment
portfolio](/wiki/Investment_portfolio "Investment portfolio") which is worth
more than £8 billion.[137]

## Online church
directory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Church_of_England&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Online church directory")]

The Church of England supports _A Church Near You_ , an [online](/wiki/Online
"Online") directory of churches. A user-edited resource, it currently lists
16,400 churches and has 7,000 editors in 42 dioceses.[138] The directory
enables parishes to maintain accurate location, contact and event information
which is shared with other websites and [mobile apps](/wiki/Mobile_app "Mobile
app"). In 2012, the directory formed the data backbone of Christmas Near
You[139] and in 2014 was used to promote the church's Harvest Near You
initiative.[140]
